content:
• Monday, January 29, 2018
  • CBS

    Grammy ratings tumble, hit all-time low in key demo

    • Of a piece with other entertainment awards shows on linear TV, ratings for last night's Grammy Awards were down significantly and hit an all-time low in the show's key demographic.
    • The show won the night for CBS (CBS -2.1%), though most rivals didn't elect to counterprogram, with only ABC airing any originals.
    • Grammy ratings dropped to 5.9 among adults 18-49, and drew 19.8M viewers, according to Nielsen -- that's down about 24% on both counts from 7.8 and 26.1M.
    • Overall the show averaged a 12.7 household rating (down from 16) and a 21 share.
    • Previously: Wells Fargo doesn't like Viacom merger idea, downgrades CBS (Jan. 29 2018)
     
     
     
     
    | 7:33 PM | 30 Comments
  • PE

    Parsley Energy -4% after production, capex guidance.

    • Parsley Energy (NYSE:PE) -3.8% after-hours following its latest operational update, which includes expectations for 2018 capex "toward the higher end of the previously issued guidance... $1.35B-$1.55B given the likelihood of service and equipment cost inflation, [which probably] would be accompanied by a disproportionate increase in cash flow generation on a steady development pace."
    • During Q4, PE says it completed 41 wells and expects to report $410M-$420M in capex, translating to FY 2017 capex of ~$1.2B.
    • PE expects Q4 overall net production of 80-81 MBoe/day and net oil production of 51-52 MBo/day, and FY 2017 net output of 68 MBoe/day and net oil output of 45 MBo/day, which would translate to respective 78% and 75% Y/Y increases.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:57 PM | 8 Comments
  • GNBC

    GNBC, EXTR, PMT rising on moves to SmallCap 600

    • Green Bancorp (NASDAQ:GNBC) is up 7.1% on word it's moving into the S&P SmallCap 600.
    • It's replacing Healthcare Services Group (NASDAQ:HCSG), which is moving up to the MidCap 400 to replace Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD), set to be acquired by Arby's. Those moves are effective before the open next Monday.
    • Meanwhile, Extreme Networks (NASDAQ:EXTR) is up 6.5% in postmarket trade as it prepares to head into the SmallCap 600 to replace Time (TIME), which is being acquired by Meredith. That move is set to come before the open on Thursday.
    • And PennyMac Mortgage Investment Trust (NYSE:PMT) has risen 5.3% postmarket as it prepares to move into the SmallCap 600 to replace Bank Mutual Corp. (NASDAQ:BKMU), set to be acquired by Associated Bancorp. That move is effective prior to the open on Friday.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:30 PM | 2 Comments

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers (1/29/2018)

    • Top gainers: PTI +13.4%. AR +5.6%. HA +4.7%. APLP +2.9%.
    • Top losers: UCTT -9.7%. RMBS -6.3%. AMRN -5.2%. MET -5.2%. PE -3.9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:35 PM | 3 Comments
  • REV

    Revlon CEO Garcia to depart, forecasts above-consensus Q4 revenue

    • Revlon (NYSE:REV) +2.5% after-hours after announcing that President and CEO Fabian Garcia is stepping down "to pursue other opportunities," and Executive Vice Chair Paul Meister will oversee operations on an interim basis.
    • REV also says it expects Q4 revenues of $785M, below $801M from the year-earlier quarter but ahead of analyst consensus estimate of $743M, and a $60M-$80M net loss for the quarter due to a charge related to the recent tax law changes.
    • REV expects Q4 adjusted EBITDA of $110M-$115M vs. $115M analyst consensus.
    • CFO Chris Peterson also denies rumors that the company is considering a material asset transfer that would shield assets from lenders.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:15 PM | 15 Comments
  • CBAY

    CymaBay readies equity offering; shares off 3% after hours

    • CymaBay Therapeutics (NASDAQ:CBAY) launches a public offering of common stock. Price, volume and terms have yet to be announced. Shares are down 3% after hours on modest volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:59 PM | 1 Comment
  • MET

    MetLife -5.3% as it postpones report amid material weakness

    • In preliminary results just released, MetLife (NYSE:MET) notes it's found a material weakness in internal controls in a review of its annuity reserves.
    • It's postponing its earnings report and conference call accordingly, to Feb. 13 after the close (and the call on Feb. 14 at 8 a.m. ET), from a previously scheduled Jan. 31 and Feb. 1.
    • Shares have slid 5.3% after hours.
    • On Dec. 15 the company said it was reviewing procedures used to estimate reserves tied to some Retirement and Income Solutions group annuitants, and says the prior release of group annuity reserves resulted from the material weakness.
    • To adjust, it expects to increase reserves between $525M-$575M pretax.
    • The total amount expected to affect Q4 net income if $135M-$165M pretax, which will be reflected in adjusted earnings as a current-period strengthening of reserves.
    • In preliminary numbers, it expects net income of $2B-$2.1B ($1.91-$1.96/share), and adjusted earnings of $650M-$700M ($0.61-$0.66/share), along with book value of $53.51-$53.56/share.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:46 PM | 21 Comments
  • RMBS

    Rambus -5.5% after Q4 results, in-line guidance

    • Rambus (NASDAQ:RMBS) shares are down 5.5% aftermarket following Q4 results that beat revenue estimates and met on EPS. In-line Q1 guidance (under ASC 605 accounting change) has revenue from $94M to $100M (consensus: $100.38M) and EPS from $0.17 to $0.23 (consensus: $0.18).
    • Revenue breakdown: Royalties, $77.9M (+10% Y/Y); Product, $8.5M (-27%); Contract and other revenue, $15.5M (+2%); Licensing billings, $76.6M (+18%).
    • Key metrics: Non-GAAP operating margin, 31%; total operating expenses, $67.5M; cash and equivalents, $172.2M; cash flow from operations, $33.3M.
    • Earnings call is scheduled for 5 PM Eastern with the webcast available here.
    • Press release
    • Previously: Rambus EPS in-line, beats on revenue (Jan. 29)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:46 PM
  • AR

    Antero Resources to evaluate potential ways to address stock price

    • Antero Resources (NYSE:AR) +2.7% after-hours as it says it will "evaluate various potential measures to address the discount in trading value of [its stock] relative to some of the premier U.S. large capitalization upstream independents."
    • "This evaluation of potential measures to address our valuation discount is a high priority within our organization and we intend to pursue it with rigor," Chairman and CEO Paul Rady says, adding that AR has received "constructive input" from some of its largest shareholders.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:35 PM | 37 Comments
  • CRBP

    Corbus Pharma on go to start mid-stage study of lenabasum in cystic fibrosis; shares up 2% after hours

    • Corbus Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:CRBP) is up 2% after hours on average volume in response to its announcement that its has reached agreement with the FDA on the design of a Phase 2b clinical trial assessing lead candidate lenabasum (formerly known as anabasum) for the treatment of cystic fibrosis (CF).
    • The primary endpoint will be the rate of pulmonary exacerbations (PEs), specifically, the average number of PEs per subject per time period. Adolescent patients aged 12 - 17 years will be included. Dosing should commence later this quarter. Target enrollment is ~415.
    • Orphan Drug- and Fast Track-tagged lenabasum is an oral synthetic endocannabinoid-mimetic that preferentially binds to the cannabinoid receptor type 2 (CB2) expressed on activated immune cells and fibroblasts. Activating CB2 triggers biochemical pathways that halt fibrosis and inflammation.
    • Management will host a conference call tomorrow, January 30, at 10:30 am ET to discuss the study.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:33 PM | 2 Comments
  • IDTI

    Integrated Device Tech +4% after Q3 beats; guidance on conference call

    • Integrated Device Tech (NASDAQ:IDTI) shares are up 4% aftermarket following Q3 results that beat EPS and revenue estimates. Q4 guidance will come on the earnings call.  
    • CEO Greg Waters attributes Q3 revenue growth to increasing demand for high-performance compute and automotive/industrial end markets. Waters expects consumer end market product cycles to kick in during Q4 and drive growth above normal seasonality.
    • Key metrics: Non-GAAP gross profit, 62.9% (+1.3 percentage points Y/Y); R&D expense, $42.8M (+$9.3M); SG&A expense, $31.1M (+$5.4M); cash and equivalents, $132.8M; total liabilities, $660.5M. 
    • Tax reform impact: The $101.9M impact that includes $10.2M from the remeasurement of deferred tax assets and liabilities at the lower corporate tax rates and $91.7M from the tax on repatriation of foreign earnings. 
    • Earnings call will begin at 4:30 PM Eastern with the webcast available here. 
    • Press release 
    • Previously: Integrated Device Tech beats by $0.01, beats on revenue (Jan. 29)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:24 PM
  • DFFN

    Late-stage study of Diffusion Pharma's TSC in brain cancer underway; shares up 4% after hours

    • Diffusion Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:DFFN) is up 4% after hours on the heels of its announcement that the first patient has been dosed in a Phase 3 clinical trial, INTACT, assessing lead candidate trans sodium crocetinate (TSC) in patients with newly-diagnosed inoperable glioblastoma multiforme (GBM), the most common type of brain tumor.
    • INTACT will compare standard-of-care radiation therapy and chemo plus TSC against standard-of-care alone. The primary endpoint is overall survival (OS) over 24 months.
    • According to ClinicalTrials.gov, the estimated primary completion date is June 2021.
    • Orphan Drug-tagged TSC is a small molecule that modifies the tumor microenvironment which improves the effectiveness of radiation therapy and chemotherapy.
    • Previously: FDA signs off on Phase 3 protocol for Diffusion Pharma's lead candidate TSC; shares ahead 75% premarket (Oct. 17, 2017)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:18 PM | 5 Comments
  • UCTT

    Ultra Clean Holdings to launch $100M offering

    • Ultra Clean Holdings (NASDAQ:UCTT) -4.5% after-hours as it announces a public offering of ~$100M in common shares, with an underwriters option to purchase additional shares.
    • UCTT says it plans to use the proceeds for general corporate purposes, which may include working capital, capital expenditures, debt repayment and potential acquisitions of complementary businesses and assets.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:16 PM | 30 Comments
  • AMRN

    Amarin readies equity offering; shares down 13% after hours

    • Amarin (NASDAQ:AMRN) slumps 13% after hours in response to its planned public offering of American Depositary Shares (ADSs). Price, volume and terms have yet to be announced.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:07 PM | 8 Comments
  • CVTI

    Covenant Transportation misses by $0.01, beats on revenue

    • Covenant Transportation (NASDAQ:CVTI): Q4 EPS of $0.50 misses by $0.01.
    • Revenue of $203.3M (+6.5% Y/Y) beats by $4.3M.
    • Shares +1.5%.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:04 PM
  • MXIM

    Maxim Integrated +12.3% on acquisition target news

    • CNBC reports that Japanese chipmaker Renesas is in talks to acquire Maxim Integrated (NASDAQ:MXIM) for up to $20B.
    • Sources note that the deal isn’t imminent and could fall through. 
    • Renesas has a market cap of $20B compared to Maxim’s $16B.
    • The two companies each attempted to acquire Intersil in 2016. Renesas won out with a $3.2B payment 
    • Maxim previously approached Analog Devices and Texas Instruments to sell itself, but the talks fell through. 
    • Maxim Integrated shares closed today up 12.3%.  
     
     
     
     
    | 4:03 PM | 4 Comments

  • Technology - Top Gainers / Losers as of 2.55 pm (1/29/18)

    • Gainers: IMMR +39%. ZDGE +14%. HMNY +13%. CISN +9%. CPAH +6%.
    • Losers: SOHU -16%. VMW -13%. SILC -13%. DVMT -12%. MRAM -11%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:55 PM
  • JD

    Tencent, JD.com investing in physical shopping via Wanda

    • JD.com (JD -0.6%) and Tencent (TCEHY -1.6%) are part of an investor group taking a 14% stake in China's biggest mall developer, part of an increasingly pitched battle to locate and draw new customers.
    • Wang Jianlin's Wanda is taking advantage of brick-and-mortar benefits of a fight between those two and Alibaba (BABA -0.4%) over consumers and data.
    • The commercial-property company faced a September deadline to relist Wanda Commercial or repay investors in full plus 10% interest, The Wall Street Journal reports.
    • But the new stake, taken for 34B yuan (about $5.37B), could clear a path for regulators to approve Wanda's relisting in Shanghai.
    • The move will give Tencent and JD a partner in shopping malls even as Alibaba looks to move into physical stores.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:43 PM | 39 Comments
  • VMW

    Deutsche Bank raises VMware price target to 17% upside

    • Deutsche Bank reaffirms its Buy rating and raises its VMware (NYSE:VMW) price target from $145 to $175 on the news that Dell is considering strategic options including a reverse merger.
    • The new target represents a nearly 17% upside on Friday’s closing price. 
    • Firm says that the investor consensus is that Dell’s debt, margin pressure, and tax reform is driving the company to explore its options. 
    • Deutsche Bank thinks VMware is in a stronger position today than when then-parent company EMC considered its strategic options in 2015.
    • Source: Briefing.com. 
    • VMware shares are down 12.9%.       
    • Previously: CNBC: VMware could buy Dell in reverse merger; VMW -7.1% (Jan. 29)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:43 PM | 7 Comments
  • JKS

    JinkoSolar signs 1.75 GW solar module U.S. supply agreement

    • JinkoSolar (JKS +2.4%) is higher after announcing a master solar module supply agreement to provide ~1.75 GW of high efficiency solar modules in the U.S. over three years.
    • JKS also says it is finalizing plans for the construction of an advanced solar manufacturing facility in the U.S.; PV Magazine reports the company will invest $410M for a U.S. headquarters and facility in Jacksonville, Fla.
    • The report says the exception for 2.5 GW of cells in last week’s solar tariff news opens the doors for foreign PV manufacturers to invest in module factories, as current demand for cells from U.S. PV manufacturers is well below 2.5 GW.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:25 PM | 4 Comments
  • ISCA

    International Speedway races to new 52-week high

    • Shares of International Speedway (NASDAQ:ISCA) are up another 6.10% to extend on last week's post-earnings rally.
    • The company more than offset a decline in Q4 admission revenue through a 3% increase in motorsports and other event revenue during the quarter.
    • International Speedway hit a 52-week high of $47.35 earlier in the day.
    • Previously: More on International Speedway Q4 (Jan. 25)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:12 PM
  • HPE

    Analyst ups HPE price target to 14% upside ahead of management meeting

    • Deutsche Bank raises its Hewlett Packard Enterprise (NYSE:HPE) price target by $3 to $19, a 13.7% upside on Friday’s closing price.
    • The increase comes ahead of the firm’s investor meetings with incoming CEO Antonio Neri, CFO Tim Stonesifer, and Head of IR Andrew Simanek. 
    • Deutsche Bank expects to discuss server market trends, 3PAR storage business underperformance, and the margin outlook.
    • Firm likes the stock as a value-play and sees on-premise spending revival as a positive growth driver for 2018. 
    • Source: Briefing.com. 
    • Hewlett Packard Enterprise shares are up 1.8%.       
     
     
     
     
    | 2:09 PM
  • GE

    GE bounces as Gabelli says he's buying

    • General Electric (GE +1.4%) shares enjoy a midday move higher following a positive mention from Mario Gabeli on CNBC.
    • Gabelli said he is just starting to buy GE and that he now owns a $40M-$50M position; he thinks the stock at ~$16 is attractive and sees it rising to the low $20s in two years.
    • He also believes oil services companies are well positioned and is adding to his holdings in Halliburton (HAL -1.1%) while buying shares of Twin Disc (TWIN +15%), sending the latter to a 52-week high.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:06 PM | 99 Comments
  • FOX

    'Maze Runner' takes top spot at box office, adding to Fox haul

    • It was Fox's (FOX +0.1%, FOXA +0.3%) turn to clean up at the box office, with Maze Runner: The Death Cure taking the No. 1 spot and Fox distributing two of the other top five.
    • The Maze Runner sequel drew $23.5M to interrupt a solid run from Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle (SNE -3.5%), which settled into the second spot with $16.4M.
    • A wide release of Entertainment Studios' Hostiles was third with $10.2M. Meanwhile, Fox's The Greatest Showman ($9.5M) and The Post ($8.85M) rounded out the top five.
    • Jumanji is still plugging along, with a light drop-off from last week and hitting $338M in cumulative domestic grosses and a total of $822M worldwide. It's now Sony's third-largest domestic release ever.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:05 PM | 1 Comment

  • Energy/Materials - Top Gainers / Losers as of 2:00 pm (1/29/2018)

    • Gainers: OSN +25%. YTEN +18%. NOG +7%.
    • Losers: NAK -23%. LTBR -15%. DELT -10%. CRR -10%. RKDA -9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:02 PM | 2 Comments
  • VIA

    Wells Fargo doesn't like Viacom merger idea, downgrades CBS

    • Wells Fargo has downgraded CBS (CBS -1.5%) to Market Perform amid growing coverage of a potential re-merger of the company with Viacom (VIA +0.1%, VIAB -0.7%).
    • "To be frank, we don't like it," says analyst Marci Ryvicker. "To us, bigger in and of itself is not necessarily better."
    • A deal might be accretive to CBS EPS in the short term, but "Unfortunately, we are more afraid of the longer-term value destruction — particularly at CBS, which we have historically favored given its clean portfolio of MUST HAVE content."
    • It's hard to see meaningful synergies now that Viacom has cut a lot of fat, she continues.
    • The firm keeps a Market Perform rating on Viacom and a $32 price target on the B shares (implying 5% downside). It cut its price target on CBS to $63 from $70, implying just 6.6% upside.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:44 PM | 7 Comments
  • WGO

    Winnebago and peers on the move

    • Shares of Winnebago (NYSE:WGO) are up 7.90% after Sidoti issues a positive assessment on industry trends.
    • Analyst Stephen O’Hara sees the inventory levels at Winnebago "appropriate" heading into the warmer weather selling season.
    • Thor Industries (THO +2.5%) and LCI Industries (LCII +1.6%) are also notably higher on the day.
    • Sources: CNBC and Bloomberg
     
     
     
     
    | 1:38 PM | 6 Comments
  • LSXMA

    Liberty Sirius XM, Pandora rise as Citi sees buyout more likely

    • Liberty Sirius XM (NASDAQ:LSXMA) is 1.3% higher, and Pandora (NYSE:P) up 4.3%, as a Citi upgrade sees a purchase of the streaming service by the satellite-radio giant getting closer.
    • The firm has lifted LSXMA to Buy, pointing to signs that suggest a buyout is near: Liberty keeps raising its stake in Sirius XM (NASDAQ:SIRI), and the company's net operating loss is soon to run out; and Liberty can use Sirius' recurring dividend for cash for the buyout.
    • Meanwhile, the purchase could narrow a 20% net asset value discount that hasn't gotten closer even as Liberty builds its Sirius stake. (h/t Bloomberg)
    • Analyst Jason Bazinet thinks some combination of SIRI and LSXMA is about two years away; he's raised his price target on LSXMA to $54 from $48, and remains a Buy on SIRI and P.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:25 PM | 9 Comments
  • AMZN

    Analyst raises Amazon to 14% upside on ad growth potential

    • Citi reiterates its Buy rating for Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) but raises the price target from $1,400 to $1,600, a 14% upside to Friday’s close. 
    • Analyst Mark May calls Amazon a “top pick in part due to the ad opportunity still being under-appreciated.” 
    • May notes that Google and Facebook combine to take 70% of the U.S. digital ad market, but Amazon can use its e-commerce operations to grow.
    • The analyst forecasts Amazon’s ad business sales to grow from $10.2B this year to $50.6B by 2028.   
    • Amazon shares are up 1.7%.    
     
     
     
     
    | 1:04 PM | 59 Comments

  • Financials - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 1:00 PM (1/29/2018)

    • Gainers: ENVA +7%.
    • Losers: MSB -9%. LMFA -7%. OPHC -6%. MLP -6%. BRG -5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:02 PM | 1 Comment
  • MPVD

    Mountain Province Diamonds to acquire Kennady Diamonds

    • Mountain Province Diamonds (MPVD -2.6%) has entered into a definitive arrangement agreement to acquire Kennady Diamonds in a friendly all-share offer.
    • Under the terms of the Transaction, Kennady shareholders will receive 0.975 of a Mountain Province common share for each Kennady common share, representing the equivalent of C$3.46/Kennady share.
    • The Exchange Ratio represents a premium of 26% to Kennady's closing price (Jan. 26th).
    • The implied equity value for Kennady based on the Exchange Ratio is ~C$176M.
    • Upon completion of the Transaction, the combined company will be owned ~76% by Mountain Province shareholders and 24% by Kennady shareholders (excl. common shares to be issued pursuant to the Private Placement).
    • CEO of Mountain Province, David E. Whittle: "The Kennady assets are a strong complement to Mountain Province's interest in the Gahcho Kué project, significantly adding to our attributed resource base. Kennady's exploration efforts have been very successful and we have high confidence in our ability to continue that success, not only through expanding the existing resources at Kelvin and Faraday but through the potential for further discoveries, not just in the Kelvin-Faraday corridor but elsewhere across the property."
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 12:59 PM

  • Midday Gainers / Losers (1/29/2018)

    • Gainers: IMMR +47%. KS +30%. OSN +28%. DPS-OLD +23%. MATX +23%. CVO +22%. BLDP +18%. AKCA +15%. PTGX +14%. KDMN +13%.
    • Losers: SMRT -30%. FWP -26%. NAK -25%. OTC:ARDM -25%. ITUS -16%. SOHU -16%. OGEN -16%. LTBR -15%. OPGN -14%. OASM -14%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM | 6 Comments
  • PBR

    Petrobras moving toward new contracts for gas, diesel distributors

    • Petrobras (PBR -1.6%) says it is working on a new contract model for gasoline and diesel distributors in an attempt to recover market share that has was lost to competition from importers.
    • "With the new contract model for gasoline and diesel oil in the pipeline, Petrobras aims to strengthen its relationship with its customers, increase its market share, and increase its competitiveness by delivering the highest level of service," the company says.
    • In the first 11 months of 2017, Brazil imported 207M barrels of refined products, 25% more than in the first 11 months of 2016 and higher than any full year on record.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:42 PM
  • ENTA

    Enanta Pharma continues northward march, up 6%

    • Thinly traded Enanta Pharmaceuticals (ENTA +6.2%) is up on average volume. Shares have rallied 75% since mid-December, riding the broad market's upsurge in general and biotech's and AbbVie's rallies in particular.
    • The company has been in a collaboration with AbbVie since December 2006 aimed at developing HCV drugs, specifically protease inhibitors, including paritaprevir and glecaprevir.
    • A key Enanta pipeline program is Phase 2-stage NASH candidate EDP-305, a farnesoid X receptor (FXR) agonist, that it says has been designed to take advantage of increased binding interactions with the receptor.
    • Previously: Enanta's NASH candidate EDP-305 shows encouraging action in early-stage study (Oct. 23, 2017)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:38 PM | 2 Comments
  • MDP

    Meredith makes Lacy executive chairman, Harty new CEO

    • Meredith (NYSE:MDP) has named its CEO/Chairman Steve Lacy the new executive chairman, and promoted Tom Harty to president and CEO, effective Feb. 1.
    • Lacy will now work with Harty on strategic agenda, while Harty will add responsibility for Meredith's finance and legal functions.
    • Harty is currently president and chief operating officer. He joined Meredith in 2004 as chief revenue officer and president of consumer magazines.
    • He already had oversight over the company's National and Local Media Groups, and he'll direct integration of Time Inc. (TIME) after that acquisition, expected to close this week.
    • Shares are up 1.7% today after the company declared a 4.8% boost to its quarterly dividend earlier.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:27 PM | 1 Comment
  • SSC-OLD

    Seven Stars Cloud working to speed financial reports

    • Among a number of business updates, Seven Stars Cloud (SSC +3.3%) says it's working with its auditor to shorten its usual time frame for issuing Q4 and full-year financials.
    • The company typically files at the end of March, but it's working to speed that despite a pressed timeline due to a two-week Chinese New Year celebration. It plans to issue 2018 guidance as soon as preliminary January revenue data is captured and reviewed at month's end.
    • It also says He Ying Private Equity Fund and Cosco -- funds set up initially just to partner with SSC on supply chain finance -- will also work on the company's asset-backed securitization and tokenization business.
    • Its SuperApp is being repurposed from a recommendation engine toward becoming a value component of the company's B2B Dynamic Business Intelligence Engine. And the company is close to securing an interim Manhattan office space while it searches for a bigger U.S. headquarters.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:07 PM | 3 Comments
  • IMMR

    Analyst raises Immersion price target to double Friday's close on settlement

    • Craig-Hallum raises its Immersion (NASDAQ:IMMR) price target by $3 to $15 on the news of the Apple settlement. The new target more than doubles Friday’s closing price.
    • Firm thinks the Apple win could bring in all three additional suits with settlements in the next year, which would push Immersion to $1.50 to $1.80 in non-GAAP EPS.
    • Firm sees Immersion as a $20+ stock if the agreement brings a wave of customer signings.
    • Immersion had filed two rounds of lawsuits against Apple in 2016 over patented haptic technology used in models of the iPhone, Watch, and MacBook lines. 
    • Source: Briefing.com.
    • Immersion shares are up 50.3%. 
    • Previously: Immersion +49% on Apple settlement (Jan. 29)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:04 PM | 12 Comments

  • Consumer - Top Gainers / Losers as of 12:00 pm (1/29/2018)

    • Gainers: KS +30%. DPS-OLD +24%. FBR +7%. DFBG-OLD +7%. WGO +5%.
    • Losers: SYPR -12%. VUZI -10%. FORD -7%. ROX -7%. NHTC -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:01 PM
  • PPC

    Morgan Stanley cautious on Pilgrim's Pride into earnings

    • Morgan Stanley is cautious on Pilgrim's Pride (PPC -2.1%) heading into the company's Q4 earnings report.
    • "We believe Q4 consensus estimates do not fully reflect recent cautious commentary by the company concerning Mexico and a more promotional US big bird pricing environment," observes the analyst team led by Matthew Grainger.
    • MS estimates a 10% EPS tailwind for Hormel from tax reform if it doesn't reinvest fund. PPC is rated at Equalweight and assigned a price target of $32.
    • Pilgrim's Pride is due to spill Q4 numbers on February 15.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:47 AM
  • VMW

    CNBC: VMware could buy Dell in reverse merger; VMW -7.1%

    • VMware (NYSE:VMW) shares plunge 7.1% after CNBC reports that the company could buy Dell in a reverse merger.
    • Dell currently owns 80% of VMware, and the sale would let Dell go public without going through a formal listing. Dell shareholders could profit while paying off part of its $50B debt. 
    • Dell could still go the IPO route. The company is considering its strategic options, which include buying up the remaining VMware or making another acquisition.
    • Previously: WSJ: Dell examines alternatives including IPO, VMware buyout (Jan. 25)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:42 AM | 9 Comments
  • INAP

    Internap +2.4% on acquisition announcement

    • Internap (NASDAQ:INAP) acquires managed hosting and IaaS business SingleHop for $132M in cash.
    • SingleHop offers automated and on-demand IT infrastructure that Internap will immediately offer to its customers. SingleHop’s existing enterprise customers will benefit from Internap’s wider geographic footprint.

    • A leaked plan where the Trump administration would push for a nationalized 5G network would be a good outcome for tower companies, Cowen says.
    • That's the opposite of the effect on big carriers AT&T (T -1.5%), Verizon (VZ -1.6%), T-Mobile (TMUS -1.2%) and Sprint (S -1.8%), working on building their own networks.
    • Current estimates for American Tower (AMT +0.1%), Crown Castle (CCI -0.5%) and SBA Communications (SBAC -0.4%) through the end of next year are assuming little if any growth from 5G, analyst Colby Synesael notes, but the report suggests faster action from government that could spur higher growth. (h/t Bloomberg)
    • Fiber companies like Zayo Group (ZAYO +0.1%) would also be beneficiaries as they built out more fiber to sites.
    • Meanwhile, FCC commissioners are coming out against the potential Trump plan. “I oppose any proposal for the federal government to build and operate a nationwide 5G network ... Any federal effort to construct a nationalized 5G network would be a costly and counterproductive distraction from the policies we need to help the United States win the 5G future," says Chairman Ajit Pai.

    FDA accepts Theravance's marketing application for COPD med revefenacin; action date November 13; shares up 2%

    • The FDA accepts for review Theravance Biopharma's (TBPH +1.5%) New Drug Application (NDA) seeking approval for revefenacin (TD-4208) for the once-daily treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The agency's action date is November 13.
    • Revefenacin, a long-acting muscarinic antagonist, is delivered via a nebulized bronchodilator. Theravance is developing and commercializing the product with Mylan NV (MYL +0.3%). Under the terms of the collaboration, Theravance has U.S. rights while Mylan has ex-U.S. rights. Theravance is eligible to receive up to $220M in milestones from Mylan as well as double-digit royalties on ex-U.S. sales. The companies will share profits on U.S. sales.
    • Theravance retains global rights to revefenacin delivered through other dosage forms (e.g., metered dose inhaler, dry powder inhaler) and rights to the nebulized form in China.

  • PTCT

    PTC Therapeutics' RG7916 shows positive effect in mid-stage SMA-1 study; shares ahead 8% premarket

    • PTC Therapeutics (NASDAQ:PTCT) is up 8% premarket on average volume in response to its announcement of positive preliminary data from a Phase 2 clinical trial, FIREFISH, assessing RG7916 in infants and babies with Type 1 spinal muscular atrophy (SMA). The results were presented at the International Scientific Congress on spinal muscular atrophy in Kraków, Poland.
    • Treatment with RG7916 was shown to be safe and well-tolerated. No patient lost the ability to swallow over a period as long as 35 weeks.
    • 77% (n=10/13) of patients experienced at least one adverse event (AE), most mild in severity and resolved despite ongoing treatment. Four subjects experienced serious AEs. There were two deaths, one from viral respiratory tract infection and the other from cardiac and respiratory arrest. No evidence of retinal toxicity was observed.
    • RG7916 is an orally administered survival motor neuron 2 (SMN2) splicing modifier. It works by targeting the underlying molecular deficiency of SMA by modulating SMN2 splicing to increase expression of full-length SMN2 mRNA from the SMN2 gene.
    • PTC licensed its SMA program to Roche (OTCQX:RHHBY) in November 2011.
    • Previously: PTC Therapeutics earns $20M milestone from Roche on advancement of SMA candidate RG7916; shares up 1% (Oct. 12, 2017)
